text: Graphic designer reports into director of content marketing. We're a very small team though :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Graphic designer reports into director of content marketing. We're a very small team though

text: We have a branding & creative department that houses content marketing, copywriting and graphic design. The head of the department is VP of Branding & Creative. Below him are the section directors, one for each discipline. So the designers roll up to the Director of Design

elements.text: We have a branding & creative department that houses content marketing, copywriting and graphic design. The head of the department is VP of Branding & Creative. Below him are the section directors, one for each discipline. So the designers roll up to the Director of Design

text: In the larger companies I’ve worked for, I’ve seen the same structure that Danielle mentions. Designers reported to an Art Director or Creative Director. For smaller companies, designers reported to a VP/Director of Marketing. I’ve overseen graphic designers as a Marketing Manager at a small start-up. Hope this helps!

text: Looking for opinions/insights: Does keyword density matter in 2021 as Google gets smarter and moves more toward fulfilling search intent?

elements.text: Looking for opinions/insights: Does keyword density matter in 2021 as Google gets smarter and moves more toward fulfilling search intent?

text: This is a great question. What I'm seeing is that keyword density is only applicable as long as you use relevant long-tail and associated keywords.

elements.text: This is a great question. What I'm seeing is that keyword density is only applicable as long as you use relevant long-tail and associated keywords.

text: I haven't paid attention to keyword density for a long time. We rank first page for google for almost everything we produce.

elements.text: I haven't paid attention to keyword density for a long time. We rank first page for google for almost everything we produce.

text: curious what <@U01PQFQBGHJ> thinks

elements.text: curious what
thinks

text: I’m seeing it still relevant in my Technical SEO and Keyword Audits, but like Ronita says you need relevant long-tail and associated keywords (not just `primary keyword` 300 times).

elements.text: I’m seeing it still relevant in my Technical SEO and Keyword Audits, but like Ronita says you need relevant long-tail and associated keywords (not just
primary keyword
300 times).

text: The way I view it: google wants well researched, relevant articles. And one sign of research + relevance is both density and diversity of keywords included in the content. (e.g., this is an article about content marketing jobs, so I might focus on secondary keywords like ‘how to get your first content marketing job’ ‘content marketing jobs starting salary’ ‘content marketing career growth plan’)

elements.text: The way I view it: google wants well researched, relevant articles. And one sign of research + relevance is both density and diversity of keywords included in the content. (e.g., this is an article about content marketing jobs, so I might focus on secondary keywords like ‘how to get your first content marketing job’ ‘content marketing jobs starting salary’ ‘content marketing career growth plan’)

text:
I don't believe `keyword density` matters anymore. We've seen cases where an article uses ~4x more of a particular term do perfectly well. And vice versa.

IMO, if your content does a great job concluding the search journey (user doesn't go back to Google and perform an additional action), then who cares how many times you use (or don't use) a term.

elements.text: I don't believe
keyword density

matters anymore. We've seen cases where an article uses ~4x more of a particular term do perfectly well. And vice versa.

IMO, if your content does a great job concluding the search journey (user doesn't go back to Google and perform an additional action), then who cares how many times you use (or don't use) a term.

text: Imo it doesn’t matter, I have pages that rank for keywords that aren’t even mentioned on the page. If you write good targeted content you’ll naturally use your keywords in the copy several times. But the number doesnt matter

elements.text: Imo it doesn’t matter, I have pages that rank for keywords that aren’t even mentioned on the page. If you write good targeted content you’ll naturally use your keywords in the copy several times. But the number doesnt matter

text: Great insights, everyone. Thanks a lot. <@U01KH3P18RZ> Can you go a little deeper into how it relates to technical SEO and how you choose what secondary keywords to target?

elements.text: Great insights, everyone. Thanks a lot.
Can you go a little deeper into how it relates to technical SEO and how you choose what secondary keywords to target?

text:
I typically:

• I use SEMRUsh’s competitive insights tool + Search Console to see what secondary keywords the post is already ranking for and where it’s _almost_ ranking. That helps inform where to add secondary keywords to add to the content. 
• I’ll do a read through of content ranking for the primary keyword 1-2 spots above us. What additional keywords are they including in the content as e.g., h2s? That helps inform where additional keywords may make sense in our piece. 
• I’ll also feed competitor content into the SEMRush Competitive Insights tool to get an idea of where they’re ranking and where we can displace them

elements.text: I typically:
I use SEMRUsh’s competitive insights tool + Search Console to see what secondary keywords the post is already ranking for and where it’s
almost
ranking. That helps inform where to add secondary keywords to add to the content.

I’ll do a read through of content ranking for the primary keyword 1-2 spots above us. What additional keywords are they including in the content as e.g., h2s? That helps inform where additional keywords may make sense in our piece.
I’ll also feed competitor content into the SEMRush Competitive Insights tool to get an idea of where they’re ranking and where we can displace them

text: Keywords in articles (and internal linking) are neighbors to technical SEO. Which not truly technical SEO, it’s something I consider on those projects.

elements.text: Keywords in articles (and internal linking) are neighbors to technical SEO. Which not truly technical SEO, it’s something I consider on those projects.

text: So, for me, it’s part iteration (e.g., launch article → see where we’re ranking + see where competitors/neighbors are ranking → iterate on content → see where we’re ranking + …), part competitive insights, and part leveraging SMEs creating the content to understand what related topics/pains/problems make sense to include to, as Bernard said, conclude the search journey.

elements.text: So, for me, it’s part iteration (e.g., launch article → see where we’re ranking + see where competitors/neighbors are ranking → iterate on content → see where we’re ranking + …), part competitive insights, and part leveraging SMEs creating the content to understand what related topics/pains/problems make sense to include to, as Bernard said, conclude the search journey.

text:
How closely you're matching Google's understanding of the topic is likely to be much more useful than literal keyword density on the target term.

I would rather see a piece of content that only uses the target keyword once and really nails all of the related phrases that match the user's intent, than see a piece of content where target head term has been used a bunch of times but writer has missed a bunch of key concepts.

In that regard `keyword density` is useful in the way that `bounce rate` is useful - even if you have context, the raw number isn't necessarily good or bad

In that regard
keyword density
is useful in the way that
bounce rate
is useful - even if you have context, the raw number isn't necessarily good or bad

text: My company is announcing an award series for brand marketers. I'm working with our designer to audit other companies that have awards series (especially B2B), so we can see what elements we should include in the microsite for our awards program —like bright colors, a unique logo, superlatives, headshots, etc. What companies do you know that run award programs, especially those that are well-designed?

text: For the most part, I’ve mainly seen designer titles denote experience/seniority like “Senior Designer,” “Junior Designer,” “Design Associate.” But, in the larger companies I’ve worked for, they would sometimes include a designer’s specialty/department in the title. For example, “Brand Designer,” “Events Designer,” etc. But I’d say the former is rare for me and the places I’ve worked.
